title: 106_hr2661
content: The Act titled "American Indian Education Foundation Act of 1999" amends Part B of subtitle II of title 36, United States Code, by adding a new chapter 216 for the American Indian Education Foundation. The American Indian Education Foundation is a federally chartered charitable and nonprofit corporation with perpetual existence, incorporated in the District of Columbia. It is not an agency or instrumentality of the United States and serves American Indian individuals and Bureau funded schools. The American Indian Education Foundation, a federally chartered nonprofit corporation, aims to support the educational opportunities of American Indians attending Bureau funded schools by accepting private gifts and collaborating with government entities. The American Indian Education Foundation collaborates with government entities to further educational opportunities for American Indians attending Bureau funded schools through a governing body known as the board of directors. The board consists of at least 11 members, including the Secretary of the Interior and the Assistant Secretary of the Interior for Indian Affairs, who serve as ex officio nonvoting members. Initial board members are appointed by the Secretary of the Interior. The board of the American Indian Education Foundation consists of at least 11 members, with the Secretary of the Interior appointing the initial members. Board members must be U.S. citizens knowledgeable in American Indian education and represent diverse viewpoints. The foundation's officers include a secretary elected from the board members, responsible for overseeing operations related to education. The American Indian Education Foundation board consists of at least 11 members appointed by the Secretary of the Interior. Board members must be U.S. citizens knowledgeable in American Indian education. The officers are elected from the board and are responsible for overseeing education operations. The board members do not receive compensation but are reimbursed for travel expenses. The foundation has powers to adopt a constitution, make contracts, acquire property, sue, and perform acts necessary for its purposes. The American Indian Education Foundation has the power to lease, encumber, and transfer property, sue and be sued, and perform acts necessary for its purposes. Its principal office is in the District of Columbia, but activities can be conducted throughout the United States. The foundation must comply with state laws on service of process and is liable for the acts of its officers and agents. Board members are personally liable only for gross negligence. The American Indian Education Foundation has restrictions on spending, limiting administrative costs to 10% of funds transferred or donated. Appointment of officers and employees is subject to fund availability. Members of the board and foundation personnel are not considered U.S. officers or employees. The Secretary of the Interior can transfer funds to the foundation from the Department of the Interior. The Secretary of the Interior can transfer funds to the American Indian Education Foundation from the Department of the Interior, as long as the funds were not donated with any prohibitions. The American Indian Education Foundation can receive funds from the Department of the Interior, provided that the funds were not donated with any restrictions. The Secretary of the Interior appoints initial voting members of the board of directors for the American Indian Education Foundation, with staggered terms. Successive boards must conform to the foundation's constitution and bylaws. The Secretary provides administrative support for a 5-year period after the enactment of the Act. During the 5-year period after the Act's enactment, the Secretary of the Interior can provide administrative support to the American Indian Education Foundation, including personnel, facilities, and funding for board members' travel expenses. The foundation must reimburse for services and funds provided. Reimbursements will be deposited in the Treasury for the deallocation of costs. The Secretary of the Interior may continue to provide facilities and support services to the foundation on a reimbursable cost basis after the initial 5-year period.
